results.byline: By Judson Jones and Eduardo Medina
results.title: Winter Storm System Brings Heavy Snow and Rain Across the U.S.
results.abstract: The system has clobbered the Sierra Nevada with snowfall of up to three inches an hour and is expected to affect travel from the Central Plains to the Upper Midwest, forecasters said.

results.title: The Misfires Are the Point: Dressing Gen Z for ‘The White Lotus’
results.abstract: The show’s costume designer sees your mean tweets. Here’s how she created the younger characters’ divisive looks.

media.caption: Portia (Haley Lu Richardson) blissing out in paradise in an embroidered sweater vest. The younger characters on “The White Lotus” express themselves “in a really adventurous, chaotic way,” according to Alex Bovaird, the show’s costume designer.

results.byline: By Mike Baker, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Ilana Marcus
results.title: Thousands of Teens Are Being Pushed Into Military’s Junior R.O.T.C.
results.abstract: In high schools across the country, students are being placed in military classes without electing them on their own. “The only word I can think of is ‘indoctrination,’” one parent said.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: Junior Reserve Officers’ Training Corps programs are supposed to be optional, but some schools have made the course a requirement.

results.title: Artemis II, Artemis III and beyond.

media.caption: A view of the moon’s surface captured by the Orion capsule on Dec. 5 during the Artemis I mission.

results.title: Army Corrects the Record About a Black Soldier Killed by a White Sergeant in 1941
results.abstract: Private Albert H. King is one of dozens of Black service members believed to have been killed on or near U.S. bases because of their race but whose stories were largely papered over.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: A white U.S. Army sergeant fatally shot a Black private in 1941 as he walked on the main road at Fort Benning near Columbus, Ga., according to military records.

results.adx_keywords: Beaches;Coast Erosion;Shipwrecks (Historic);Archaeology and Anthropology;Meide, Chuck;Daytona Beach Shores (Fla);Florida
results.byline: By Christine Hauser and Jesus Jiménez
results.title: That Mysterious Object on a Florida Beach? It’s a Shipwreck.
results.abstract: Last month people noticed wood jutting from the sand in Daytona Beach Shores. Speculation ran wild, but archaeologists now say it was a ship, most likely a 19th-century merchant vessel.

media.caption: Archaeologists studying a wooden structure in the sand in Daytona Beach Shores, Fla., on Tuesday. A maritime archaeologist said it was most likely the wreck of a merchant ship from the 1800s.

results.title: What’s More Important for This Town: A Library or a Police Station?
results.abstract: In a community known for cross-country glory, the library is a vital resource for families who eke out a living in the fields. But city leaders want their crowded police force to move in.

results.title: How a Hotel Was Converted into Housing for Formerly Homeless People
results.abstract: Though Mayor Eric Adams estimated that 25,000 hotel rooms could be turned into supportive and affordable housing, only one building has been converted so far. And it was in the works before the plan.

results.title: Belgian Investigation Into Suspected Qatar-Linked Bribery Stuns European Parliament
